newsitem.title: USA: BT, MCI deal would be biggest yet in industry.
newsitem.headline: BT, MCI deal would be biggest yet in industry.

text.p: A merger between British Telecommunications Plc and MCI Communications Corp. could be the biggest yet in the rapidly changing telecommunications industry and the second largest involving a U.S. company.
If completed, a deal would also rank as the biggest trans-Atlantic merger, according to Securities Data Corp., which tracks and values mergers.

Washington-based MCI, the nation's second-biggest long-distance carrier, said Friday it was in talks to be bought by British Telecom, and industry analysts speculated that a deal could be worth about $22.1 billion.

That would be bigger than the proposed merger between Nynex Corp. and Bell Atlantic Corp., two regional Bell companies, worth $21.3 billion, according to Securities Data. The merger was announced on April 22 and the companies hope to complete it by year-end or early in 1997.

The British Telecom-MCI deal would be the largest between a British and American company, and it would rank as the second biggest ever involving a U.S. company, behind the RJR Nabisco Inc. buyout by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. worth $30.6 billion including debt, according to Securities Data.

Other big telecommunications mergers include SBC Communications Inc.'s proposed $16.5 billion takeover of Pacific Telesis Group, announced on April 1, and AT&T Corp.'s purchase of McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. in 1994 for $15.65 billion. The values are from Securities Data.

MCI said it expected talks to conclude this weekend but noted there were no guarantees an agreement would be reached. A spokesman for British Telecom confirmed the British company was interested in a merger with MCI.

Industry analysts speculated that a final deal would price MCI at about $40 a share, making the 80 percent that British Telecom does not already own worth $22.11 billion, based on MCI's 691 million shares outstanding.

British Telecom wants to offer a blend of cash and stock for the rest of MCI, a source close to the deal told Reuters. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a price was not finalised but that an announcment was expected on Sunday, if not before.

In Washington, lawyers and analysts said a British Telecom-MCI deal would probably win approval from U.S. regulators. Federal rules adopted last year allow a foreign carrier to buy more than 25 percent of a domestic telecom company if the overseas company's home market is deemed open to competition.
